Summary: The Juan de Fuca Marine Trail is a multi-day hike along some of British Columbia’s most pristine and stunning coastal landscape. The route follows the coastline along Vancouver Island, Canada, and takes hikers to numerous grottos, tide pools, beaches, forest, cultural points of interest, and campsites. While most avid backpackers will find this route not too difficult, it is important to say that parts of this long hike are strenuous, especially deep in the middle of the route in Juan de Fuca Provincial Park. Hikers often split this hike into three or four days, depending on experience and passion level, since shorter hikes make for more stops and nature moments. This trail starts to the town of Sooke at the southend, along China Beach at the Parkinson Trailhead and takes folks to the wonderful Botanical Beach close to Port Renfrew. Some people decide to do a return trip to get this scenery in twice, or people can even continue along the West Coast Trail to make the adventure much longer. Once departed the first beach, the trail moves through a few small beaches, thick rainforest, rock/tide pools, and over some nice hills with amazing views of the fauna, flora, and landscape. At a few places along the route, hikers may even have the opportunity to participate in surfing or kayaking, since tour operators do permit backcountry lessons during the summer months. Just be prepared to wait in lines for this, if coming to do those. Along the way, hikers should keep an eye out for wooden signs with orange markings to best follow this route. During the summer months, hikers can also use the West Coast Trail Express to return back to their starting point, if dropping a car off at the end of the trail was not an option.

Explore this 3.4-km loop trail near Cherry Point, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 59 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. Stony Hill is a quiet, peaceful walk with extraordinary views of Sansum Narrows. It's a clear, obvious paths that offers beautiful views. The trail is well marked at the beginning and end. There is an area that gets a little bit steep at one point and has some rocks and roots but is very doable for most skills levels. This is a fairly busy trail so expect company on your hike. Decent shoes with grip are a plus as there's lots of incline and decline on the way, but they are not too difficult

Discover this 4.5-km loop trail near Saanich, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. The trail is really easy to follow, and locals recommend hiking there in the morning or evenings when there are fewer people. There are plenty of other small trails to add to this main loop around the mountain. This is a fun little loop with great views of the Saanich Sea and Victoria and the surrounding area. There is a light scramble at the summit, wearing proper appropriate footwear is recommended.

Explore this 5.0-km loop trail near View Royal, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 8 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas. Upper Thetis Lake is a beautiful lake surrounded by cliffs of varied heights, creating a stunning backdrop. During the warmer months, people often kayak, paddleboard, and enjoy the soothing waters. The lake's pristine surface attractively reflects the surrounding trees. The trail consists of gravel and packed dirt. All of the sections have informative signage to guide you. You'll see a variety of ecosystems while strolling along the Upper Thetis Trail, including lakes, woodlands, and swamps. The trail has spring wildflowers, Douglas-fir forests, and Garry oak ecosystems. There are also picnic places and benches where you can unwind and enjoy the natural beauty of the surroundings

Get to know this 3.1-km loop trail near View Royal, British Columbia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 43 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas. The stunning lake, encircled by towering cliffs, can be reached via the Lower Thetis Lake Trail and the Trillium Trail Loop. Thetis Lake's immaculate surface reflects the nearby trees, creating a serene environment where kayakers and paddleboarders frequently enjoy the quiet waters. The trail comprises compacted dirt and gravel and has educational signs. You'll pass by Douglas-fir forests, Garry oak ecosystems, and springtime wildflowers. You will come to the Trillium Trail as you proceed. This section offers a range of perspectives and locations with access to the water and beautiful green jungles.

Try this 5.6-km out-and-back trail near South Saanich 1, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a very popular area for hiking and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are January through November. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This trail on the north side of Mount Work is well marked and well maintained, although it does intersect with lots of unmarked mountain biking trails. It's steep in parts, making for a great cardio workout. There is a marker that indicates you’re almost there. There's a picturesque view of the Saanich Inlet shortly before the summit. At the actual summit there isn’t a marker but it’s clearly the ‘end of the line’ with great views of Bear Mountain and Mount Finlayson. Trekking poles are helpful for this one, certainly not necessary, but helpful. It can be busy sometimes, so expect a crowd if you go on weekends. It’s a nice enough view from the top, but if it’s views you’re going for, try the nearby Jocelyn Hill.

Explore this 9.3-km loop trail near Highlands, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 13 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and snowshoeing, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This pleasant mountain trail offers gradual elevation gain with many viewpoints throughout. The trail is easy to follow with very good markings and directions throughout the route, and is also well-maintained by the city parks commission. Much of the trail runs through the thick forest with great overhead canopies, so this route is very doable even on a hot day or during the winter when it can be downpouring. The areas higher in elevation have the best views of Finlayson Arm, and the tunnel is an interesting feature that makes this trail especially unique and fun for folks looking for variety. It can be common to see bears in between Holmes Peak and Caleb Pike, so make sure to hike in groups when venturing further out into the trails and make noise during the summer and fall

Check out this 4.3-km loop trail near Langford, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 6 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding, camping, and hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This trail begins from the Goldstream Campground parking lot and first visits the beautiful Goldstream Falls. Parking is free at the campground and but it can fill up by the middle of the day. The trails are clearly marked with lots of signage throughout. Bringing sturdy and waterproof shoes is recommended since this trail is a little rugged, with mud to go through and fallen branches to climb over. The trail briefly crosses through the campground and visits Arbutus Loop before heading back to the starting point. The sound of running water throughout the park can be loud at times and make it more difficult for animals to hear you coming, so be sure to be extra bear aware - especially as during the autumn season.

Enjoy this 10.0-km loop trail near Metchosin, British Columbia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 12 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. The first three kilometres are very gentle, the path before the summit loop is flat and gravel. Once you reach the incline on Braden Summit Trail the path becomes less maintained and the markers can be difficult to locate. Downloading the map is recommended as cell service is unreliable in this area. There are some areas that are very steep and require scrambling, with large steps up onto and down from rocks.

Trail name: Anderson Cove and Copper Mine Loop
Summary: Head out on this 6.9-km loop trail near East Sooke, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 2 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and snowshoeing, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. A great loop with amazing views of Iron Mine Bay. Park at the end of a little gravel road. The trails are pretty wide for a good chunk of the hike, but gets a bit narrow and a little overgrown when you hit Coast Trail, the views are well worth it. Be cautious on the Coast Trail as it can feel narrow and there is a significant drop. The hike back on Anderson Cove trail portion also has some nice vistas and elevation that gets the heart pumping a bit. Overall, inclined and declines aren't too bad. It really is a great hike with a diversity of ups and downs, wide and narrow trails, rocky and soft, trees, ferns, shrubs, and coast. A great way to spend a couple of hours.

Enjoy this 4.3-km out-and-back trail near East Sooke, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 0 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This trail begins from the Pike Road Trailhead, which can be accessed by following Pike Road just off of East Sooke Road. Follow the Pike Road Trail towards Iron Mine Bay and cross Pine Creek. Once you cross Pine Creek follow the trail to Pike Point. Enjoy and make sure you wear proper footwear as the rocks are slippery when wet. There are great ocean views on the way

Discover this 6.0-km out-and-back trail near Sooke, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 7 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, mountain biking, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This relatively short hike is along an easy to follow trail ending in a beautiful view. It's a steady incline along a largely shaded logging road for most of the trail, with a bit of a steeper grade closer to the top. The trail is often shared with trail runners and mountain bikers. There are lots of other routes to explore in the area!

Check out this 11.7-km loop trail near Sooke, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 58 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Explore this 1.1-km out-and-back trail near Capital H , British Columbia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 20 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through January. A a very short nature walk from the parking lot to Sheringham Point Lighthouse. Overall, it is a nice little historic site to venture to. It's all downhill to the point so it's all uphill back. The trail is maintained and easy to follow, perfect for a quick detour. If you're lucky you will see some marine critters! This trail is only accessible during certain hours of the day. For more information, please visit https://sheringhamlighthouse.ca/.

Trail name: Swallow Creek and Priest Cabin Park Trail
Summary: Experience this 2.4-km out-and-back trail near River Jordan, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 0 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, hiking, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through September.

Get to know this 1.8-km out-and-back trail near Capital H , British Columbia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 26 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and walking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are February through September. While this is a short hike, it is very much worth the trip. You'll drop quickly through a lush portion of the forest and right onto a beautiful beach. Turn a left on the beach, and head down a short distance to the falls. There aren't any really technical sections, but there are some steps and some tree roots on the path. Depending on the time of season, the falls may or may not have a heavy flow.

It features beautiful waterfalls, small ocean beach caves, and beaches. There are lots of roots and some muddy areas at times, but most have a slight detour around them. Be mindful that there is minimal to no cell service in the area. This is a popular trail for backpacking, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through September. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Get to know this 42.8-km point-to-point trail near Gordon River 2, British Columbia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 14 h 8 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas. This route goes through a mix of biomes, with meadows, lakes, forests, bogs, and ponds. The meadows and bogs can be very wet in the shoulder seasons of spring and autumn. The trail was beautiful and there are huts along the way that are well-maintained. The first two thirds of the trail are located on crown land, while the final section is on private land. The path run through a working forest so it is especially important to stay on the trails near active harvesting. Some sections of the trail can be overgrown and will require bush-whacking.

Get to know this 2.9-km out-and-back trail near Sooke, British Columbia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 46 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, birding, and camping, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. Located along the shores of the Strait of Juan De Fuca, China Beach is a wonderful spot for exploring with the whole family and has fine sand which is great for sandcastle building and relaxing. To reach the beach, start from the China Beach day-use parking lot and walk down the worn trail located east of the parking lot. This well-worn trail guides you through the mature forest directly to the beach. You can walk along the beach in either or both directions. Second Beach can be reached along the beach from China Beach.

Check out this 2.9-km out-and-back trail near Juan de Fuca, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 40 min to complete. This is a very popular area for camping, hiking, and paddle sports, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This trail takes hikers down to Sombrio Beach and along the coast, where there are two backcountry campgrounds. Continuing south along the shore, the trail leads to a beautiful hidden waterfall that has created a very pretty small gorge. Be sure to check the tide tables before heading out - you can’t get around the corner if the tide is high.

Check out this 6.4-km out-and-back trail near Juan de Fuca, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 43 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are July through August. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This trail is a segment of the Juan de Fuca Marine Trail used to access Providence Cove. The trail begins at the Parkinson Creek Parking Lot, where washrooms are also available. The route can get muddy in some places with roots and logs to cross. There's not much elevation, and it is well marked and an easy to follow trail through the forest

Trail name: West Coast Trail: Thrasher Cove to Gordon River
Summary: Part of a bigger hike: Try this 5.5-km point-to-point trail near Port Renfrew, British Columbia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 6 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are May through September.

Costal+forest: Try this 33.2-km out-and-back trail near Neah Bay, Washington. Generally considered an easy route. This is a popular trail for road biking and scenic driving, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime.

Explore this 7.6-km out-and-back trail near Gordon River 2, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 46 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This is a great well-maintained trail to the beautiful Anderson Lake and its gravel beach. Follow the flags and you will have no problem finding your way! Couple this with a short detour to Walbran Falls for some more views. After some stairs and wooden boards at the beginning, it's fairly flat terrain. The lake is gorgeous and warm in the summer, and home to many trouts!

Trail name: West Coast Trail: Tsusiat Falls - Cribs Creek
Summary: costal hike part of the bigger west coast trail, waterfalls and forest. Experience this 17.2-km point-to-point trail near Bamfield, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 53 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, birding, and camping, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October.

Trail name: West Coast Trail: Michigan Creek to Tsusiat Falls
Summary: Rope bride, ladders, costal, lots of bridges, part of the bigger west coast trail

Trail name: West Coast Trail: Pachena Bay to Michigan Creek
Summary: lighthouse, wooden bridges, wildlife, can be muddy, great views, part of the bigger west coast trail

riverside hike, Check out this 6.1-km out-and-back trail near Cowichan Valley F, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 20 min to complete. This trail is great for birding, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

Trail name: Keeha Beach via Cape Beale-Keeha Trailhead
Summary: Enjoy this 9.8-km out-and-back trail near Bamfield, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 25 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, birding, and camping, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are July through September. This rugged trail brings you to the secluded, white sandy beach of Keeha Bay. Most of the trail is through thick rainforest and is muddy, often requiring going around and over fallen trees. Proper footwear is highly recommended. Rope is available to aid with the steeper slopes near the end before the beach. Wildlife such as seals, osprey, sea lions, and even black bears can be seen on the pathway and beach. Campers should register online before camping here. costal caves
Costal rocky hike with caves

experience this 2.7-km out-and-back trail near Port Alberni, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 40 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, hiking, and snowshoeing,Great trail that starts near an active logging road. Access should be restricted to the weekend. Lots of rocks and roots make footing hard. The last section is super steep with huge boulders. This section can get quite slippery after rainfall. There is a sign beside the yellow gate indicating where the trail starts. The trail is easy to follow and well-marked. There are ropes to assist in climbing the steep part. The waterfall is an amazing sight to see and is well worth the trip!

Trail name: Alberni Inlet, Scout Camp Beach, Mount Hankin Bluffs
Summary: Enjoy this 10.0-km loop trail near Port Alberni, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 41 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through November. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas. Starting from the beginning of the Alberni Inlet Trail off of Ship Creek Road, this route goes through Alberni Valley down to a viewpoint over Alberni Inlet. It then visits Scout Camp Beach, and climbs up to a viewpoint over Mount Hankin Bluffs. Alberni Inlet Trail continues south along the shore for quite a while if wanting to extend the trip. The route goes through a mix of forest, coastal trails and logging roads and is easy to follow and dog-friendly. If you're just here for the views, there are alternate parking options closer to the viewpoints that take off some hiking distance.

ry this 2.1-km loop trail near Nanaimo H, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 48 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are June through August. Horne Lake Caves Provincial Park offers something for everyone. Trails within this park can be enjoyed as a hike or below ground in the caves. There is a suspension bridge and several metal boardwalks with open grates and open metal stairs. Going into the caves requires booking a tour but you will learn a lot from your guide and the inside of the caves is worth the trip. Hiking shoes & gloves are recommended. You will get dirty in the caves as you scramble over the rocks and bend into the crevices

head out on this 6.0-km out-and-back trail near Comox Valley A, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are February through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Rosewall Creek Trail is a beautiful hike to do solo or with family or friends. There are a few spots to watch for roots but for the most part, the trail is relatively flat with a small incline to get to the best part of the falls. For folks requiring wheelchair-accessible areas, the shorter route to the picnic area and washrooms are fitting. 

Enjoy the old and second-growth forest full of moss, and the sound of rushing water at the falls. Much of the trail follows the right side of the riverbank since the left side is washed out and not good for hiking.

You will pass Bannon Falls on the way to the final destination, Rosewall Creek Falls.

Check out this 5.6-km out-and-back trail near Nanaimo F, British Columbia. Generally considered a challenging route. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and snowshoeing, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This trail starts out with a very steep uphill climb for the first kilometre but it evens out quite nicely after the Cameron Lake lookout point. Once arrived at Wesley Ridge, users recommend spending time here instead of continuing along the hike if not looking for more distance, since the views do not really improve. Hiking poles are very helpful on the descent, and overall this is a great fun workout with nice views!!

Proceed cautiously on this 6.3-km out-and-back trail near Alberni-Clayoquot F, British Columbia. Generally considered a highly challenging route, it takes an average of 4 h 40 min to complete and should only be attempted by experienced adventurers. This is a popular trail for hiking, snowshoeing, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. While Mount Arrowsmith is a good year round hike when prepared, most hikers suggest waiting for the snow to be more clear in the spring and summer, as only users experienced with winter summiting should be hiking here during the deep winter. This is a difficult ascent, and most hikers should plan on a minimum of two hours of grueling hiking to reach the peak.You will then trek up a smaller overgrown logging road until you come to the actual trailhead entrance - and from there be prepared for the upward climb. Some sections of the trail have experienced trail erosion during the spring melt and from logging operations so any hikers should absolutely be prepared with good footwear and poles

Experience this 6.4-km out-and-back trail near Nanaimo C, British Columbia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 14 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and snowshoeing, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are August through August. The trail access is closed weekdays due to logging activity. Weekend gate opening/closing times varies based on the time of year. Always consult Mosaic Forest Managements access page. The gates are approximately one hour from the trailhead in a low-clearance car. This trail offers spectacular views after a steep incline of switchbacks, an open meadow, and a climb through forest. This route follows a nice snowshoeing trail.

Trail name: Jedediah Island: Deep Bay to Home Bay
Summary: Hike on an island, Enjoy this 2.9-km out-and-back trail near Powell River E, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 43 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Tressel bridge, river, natural bridges over streams, forest hike. Check out this 3.4-km loop trail near Qualicum, British Columbia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 52 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are January through June.

This is an easy trail along the river and through some forested trails. There are big cedar trees to see along the way and beautiful mossy pathways with lots of log river crossings. There has been a ton of work at this hatchery to try to help a few different species of salmon. The nature is stunning but be aware that you may see a bear or two

Explore this 7.7-km out-and-back trail near Cherry Creek, British Columbia. Generally considered a challenging route. This is a popular trail for hiking, snowshoeing, and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. This is a beautiful hike, and is quite a workout! The trail starts with a steep climb up from the lake, then includes a short hike along a gravel road, and then moves back into the forest for a scramble up the mountain. For up to date information, please see the park page here: http://bcparks.ca/explore/parkpgs/

This short and easy trail takes you to one of the hidden secrets in the Valley of Trails, Hole in the Wall. The hole was once a shortcut for the city's waterline and today is a picturesque waterfall on Vancouver Island. While the trail mostly consists of old roads, it is wise to not travel it during the winter months, as they are bound to get quite waterlogged and muddy. Taking a side trail will take you to a lovely waterfall. The area has been previously logged, but the forests are still lovely during the spring and summer months. The network of trails and logging roads in the area is dense. Checking maps often throughout your journey will help ensure you stay on your intended path

This is an easily accessible hike from a decommissioned logging road. Access is from opposite side of road to Sproat Lake Landing. You will follow an old cut through for power lines until it branches off then follow the orange blazes. It’s uphill but not too steep, although it gets fairly technical at times. You’ll see the small trail entrance on the left hand side again marked by orange blazes. Follow that until the branch, right hand side is pink and will take you to the top. Left hand side is orange and involves a steep climb down using the ropes there. This is a beautiful spot with cold cold water at base of falls

High mountain: explore this 15.4-km out-and-back trail near Nanaimo H, British Columbia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 40 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, snowshoeing, and running, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

The drive from the highway takes approximately 45 minutes. High clearance four-wheel drive vehicles are recommended for the last kilometre. If you do not have a high-clearance vehicle, folks recommend parking the car at the first large ditch, which is about four kilometres and 420 metres elevation below where good clearance vehicles can park. The trail has really great signage.

Once hiking, you will enjoy great views of the Coast Mountains from Mount Joan.

High mountain: Experience this 14.5-km out-and-back trail near Mud Bay, British Columbia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 6 h 16 min to complete. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anyti

Trail name: China Bowls via Davis Lake Main
Summary: Discover this 3.9-km out-and-back trail near Cumberland, British Columbia. Generally considered an easy route. This is a very popular area for mountain biking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Also known as the Cumberland or Perseverance Potholes located next to Perseverance Creek, this unique hike is a perfect adventure for anyone looking for a scenic and special destination in a short amount of time. The trail leading up follows a gravel dirt road. However, once you reach your destination this is a gorgeous place to sit and relax as the bowls are quite lovely natural formations. If you're looking to see the bowls full, you might want to go during the spring. It's a pleasant way to spend an afternoon and the pools are very pretty.

Historical landmark of plane crash: The terrain can be muddy and slippery, especially after rain. The trail is primarily covered with trees, which provide plenty of shade as you hike deeper into the forest. You'll come across many fallen trees along the path. Further along, you'll reach a graffiti-covered building. As you climb the stairs of this structure, you'll come across signage that details the history of the plane crash. The trail is marked with colorful tapes. After crossing the building, you'll see walking platforms. 

As you approach the Canso Bomber Crash Site, the trail widens and is steeper with tangled roots. Eventually, you'll come across the plane's ruins, including a path leading down to the aircraft's tail. Exercise caution around the plane crash since sharp edges may exist.

Trail name: Landslide Lake via Elk River Trail
Summary: This route begins on Gold River Highway 28, roughly an hour away from Campbell River. There is no cell signal anywhere along the trail or within the park, so downloading the offline maps in advance is recommended. The trail is well-maintained. It is straight forward and has a gradual ascent. The parking lot is small and can get full pretty quickly on summer days. The trail crosses multiple streams, waterfalls and has plenty of water sources that are suitable for drinking. There are only two designated camping areas. The first campsite is 7.5 kilometres into the route and the second campsite is after 11 kilometres. After the second campsite, it will take approximately 3 kilometres to get to Landslide Lake and from there, another 2 kilometres to get to Berg Lake. The trail does not get challenging until you leave the second campsite to get to the two lakes. The hike towards Berg Lake is the more difficult part of this trail and can be tricky with lots of slippery and rocky areas. This trail can be completed as a day-hike with an early start. Both campsites have pit toilets, bear caches and cables for hanging bear bags

Head out on this 4.7-km loop trail near Campbell River 11, British Columbia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 1 h 10 min to complete. This is a very popular area for birding, hiking, and snowshoeing, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This is a great trail where you have a good chance to see bears eating salmon in the fall, as there are lots of fly fishing going on. There is one steep section with stairs and a suspension bridge over the water. Easily accessible and enough local traffic that you don't want to feel too alone. If solitude is more important, this would be ideal very early in the morning. The river is soothing and peaceful to hear during the trek. This trail is great for dogs on leash and for kids as well, but the platforms and suspension bridge can be rough on dog paws. You can expect the trails to be quite muddy during the spring and fall too

Get to know this 6.0-km loop trail near North Saanich, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 39 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. This park is fabulous and the trails are beautiful. The route includes lots of other trails that users can meander to enjoy the views at Pickles Bluff, which are amazing. The other viewpoints are nice as well, and worth exploring. Since this loop is short and it connects to other trails, hikers can also connect to some little viewpoint trails to make this an even better experience!

Features rock climbing locations: Check out this 1.8-km loop trail near Cumberland, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 32 min to complete. This trail is great for birding and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are June through September.

This trail beginning from Cumberland Campground is well maintained with some switchbacks. Good footwear is recommended for this route as the trail is steep at times. Beautiful views of Comox Lake. Young children will need some assistance at some parts for safety. There's a great waterfal at the end and an awesome view of Comox Lake.

Trail name: Helen Mackenzie to Battleship Lake Loop Trail
Summary:
Get to know this 8.5-km loop trail near Comox Valley C, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 30 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking, snowshoeing, and running, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

Half of the trail follows boardwalks and the other half is on regular trails. This beautiful and somewhat rugged trail passes through forest, over swamps, around ponds, and past two beautiful lakes. 

It can get a bit muddy in the fall and spring, although there are boardwalks over the worst of it. During the winter, it is possible to snowshoe this route and even walk out onto the lakes when safe.

Mountain climb, Proceed cautiously on this 5.0-km out-and-back trail near Tsa Xana 18, British Columbia. Generally considered a highly challenging route, it should only be attempted by experienced adventurers. This trail is great for hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring.

This is an unmarked trail that leads to a beautiful view of Cox Bay and the open ocean. It is a must-do if visiting the Tofino area! The trail is not well-marked and having the GPS handy to find the beginning of the trail through the forest is recommended. Make sure to wear ankle-high shoes and long socks as it can get pretty muddy at a few scrambly sections. some scrambling.

Head out on this 7.4-km loop trail near Tofino, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 1 h 59 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are April through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash. The Esowista Peninsula Loop takes you through diverse landscapes, including lush forests and stunning coastal views that surround the popular town of Tofino. This scenic trail offers a peaceful escape where you can enjoy a variety of plant and animal life along the way. This combines a lot of great spots that are all accessible close to town, with highlights being Tonquin Beach and Third Beach. You don't have to start at Bella Pacifica Campsite, you can also start from Arnet Road.

Explore this 48.8-km out-and-back trail near Holberg, British Columbia. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 13 h 11 min to complete. This is a popular trail for backpacking, camping, and hiking, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are May through September. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail. The beaches of Cape Scott Park are incredibly beautiful and well worth the hike in.The trail from the parking lot to Nels Bight and beyond to Cape Scott is fairly easy and fairly flat, though muddy year-round in spots. What gets most hikers are the sore and blistered feet from the pack weight and uneven ground. Wearing good hiking footwear is recommended and take care of the blisters at the first sign of them. Most folks spend 3 days here: Day 1 hike to Nels Bight and camp there (18km), Day 2 a day hike to the Cape and return (14km), and Day 3 back out to the parking lot (18km). A day hike or overnight camping at San Josef Bay (3-4km from the parking lot) is an easy hike and over a well-groomed gravel trail. Features wildlife, boardwalks and some mud, lots of bear and wolves

Check out this 3.9-km out-and-back trail near Port Hardy, British Columbia. Generally considered a moderately challenging route. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome and may be off-leash in some areas. This 2km trail takes you to a 1945 Dakota plane crash site. The trail is a bit overgrown and rather rough with mud year-round, and also a couple of rope sections. Park at the Bear Cove Boat Launch parking lot and walk down the road toward the ferry about 100m and the trail will be the paved road heading uphill on your right. Near the top of the paved road section, the pavement heads right, but the trail heads LEFT. From there the trail is fairly obvious. The road/gravel road section makes up about half the trail, then the trail turns right where you're looking out over Hardy Bay, then heads into the rugged North Island bush.

Proceed cautiously on this 44.4-km point--point trail near Tsulquate 4, British Columbia. Generally considered a highly challenging route, it takes an average of 12 h 24 min to complete and should only be attempted by experienced adventurers. This is a popular trail for backpacking, birding, and camping, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are May through September. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail. Cape Scott Provincial Park's North Coast Trail is a multi-day hike along the northern coast of Vancouver Island. The minimum hiking duration is 5 days; however, it is most typically done in 6 to 8 days. Hiking times are estimated based on a typical hiker in good physical condition and favourable weather. The first 10 kms is considered “ the bog slog”. After Sutil there is a combination of inland traversing and pebble beach hiking

Discover this 3.1-km loop trail near Ucluelet, British Columbia. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 45 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking, running, and walking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

This easy coastal path is a great walk around the coastal headlands. There are views of the Barkley Sound, Amphitrite Lighthouse, Inspiration Point, and He-Tin-Kis Beach. It's a gorgeous walk along the Pacific Coast.

Give yourself extra time on this one to pop out to several of the overlook spots, especially the one near the northernmost point of the hike. Views of the rocky cliffs and little islands are amazing. This is a fantastic hike, and it is not difficult at all. Just some gentle up and down, perfect for kids and families.

There are no stairs on this route and motorized wheelchairs may be able to navigate the path (there is a paved pathway to the lighthouse only). Check with Ucluelet's Wild Pacific Trail.
Mountain climb near Sayward British Columbia, Steep straight up for about 30 minutes and then walking along the peaks which is beautiful.

Experience this 19.2-km out-and-back trail near Cowichan Valley I, British Columbia. Although the trail is marked, in the snow it is easy to lose one's way in the alpine meadow and wouldn't suggest doing the hike without a GPS. The trek up is very steep and same with this trek down making it hard on the body both ways.
